feedback.feedback_explanation: The possessive of a singular noun like "Mr Smith" is formed by adding an apostrophe + s.
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Add "s" after the apostrophe to fix this possessive.

instance_text.source: If you are going to begin playing football, you need football shoes. You also need protection for the legs.
instance_text.corrected: If you are going to begin playing football, you need football boots. You also need protection for the legs.

report: Both grammatically valid; more context is necessary.

instance_text.source: It appealed to experts in political circles in the United States to invest more money in public transportation and improving security in the ways of the infantry in cities and make them more attractive to encourage people to use public transport.
instance_text.corrected: It appealed to experts in political circles in the United States to invest more money in public transportation and improve security in the ways of the infantry in cities and make them more attractive to encourage people to use public transport.

report: The “error“ is acceptable; correction not necessary.

instance_text.source: Suddenly, a man in black told us that we were plug the machine into the electricity.
instance_text.corrected: Suddenly, a man in black told us that we should plug the machine into the electricity.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Were" can not be used as a modal or helping verb with "plug."
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Consider using a modal verb like "should," "must," or "could."

instance_text.source: For references, you can contact the principal of the school, who will be happy to supply you [NONE] any information.
instance_text.corrected: For references, you can contact the principal of the school, who will be happy to supply you with any information.

feedback.feedback_explanation: The verb "supply" uses the pattern "supply (person) with (something)." You are missing the preposition "with."

instance_text.source: Kate was crying a lot but Michael run away.
instance_text.corrected: Kate was crying a lot but Michael ran away.

feedback.feedback_explanation: It seems like this happened in the past, but "run" is not in a past tense form.

instance_text.source: So TV could become a useful tool in the educational process if more effort is put into this, from the television programming to the preference of society.
instance_text.corrected: So TV could become a useful tool in the educational process if more effort was put into this, from the television programming to the preference of society.

feedback.feedback_explanation: In a conditional like this, the verb must be in a past or subjunctive form if the situation is hypothetical.
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Change "is" to a past or subjunctive form.

instance_text.source: Computers will write what you think, the mobiles will be smaller and lighter.
instance_text.corrected: Computers will write what you think, [NONE] mobiles will be smaller and lighter.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Mobiles" refers to mobile phones in general, so it does not need an article here.

instance_text.source: The environment is our surroundings. There is no awareness in our locality. They are busy with their own work. No one focuses on or sees what [NONE] happening in our town. They usually speak about how hot it is today, but they don't know what makes it this hot. I am interested in planting trees and making our surroundings clean. Some people used to burn the forest as if the forest is useless. Man is greedy because all the things we get from the forests are free.
instance_text.corrected: The environment is our surroundings. There is no awareness in our locality. They are busy with their own work. No one focuses on or sees what is happening in our town. They usually speak about how hot it is today, but they don't know what makes it this hot. I am interested in planting trees and making our surroundings clean. Some people used to burn the forest as if the forest is useless. Man is greedy because all the things we get from the forests are free.

feedback.feedback_explanation: To talk about something that is happening now, use the present continuous tense with "be + verb (-ing form)."
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Add a form of the verb "be" before "happening."

instance_text.source: This restaurant is very big, [NONE] we wouldn't have a problem.
instance_text.corrected: This restaurant is very big, so we wouldn't have a problem.

feedback.feedback_explanation: This is a run-on sentence. It must be broken up or connected more smoothly.
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Consider adding a conjunction here to connect the two clauses and show their relationship.

instance_text.source: When the night comes, I went to the restaurant that he invited me to go to.
instance_text.corrected: When the night came, I went to the restaurant that he invited me to go to.

feedback.feedback_explanation: It seems like this happened in the past, but you are not using a past-tense verb here.

instance_text.source: As a result of what I have just said, in my opinion, people won't have a 'real life'. Everyone will always be more involved in virtual life, so that they will forget how to talk to each other and how [NONE] express their own feelings!
instance_text.corrected: As a result of what I have just said, in my opinion, people won't have a 'real life'. Everyone will always be more involved in virtual life, so that they will forget how to talk to each other and how to express their own feelings!

feedback.feedback_explanation: "How" needs a to-infinitive (to + base form of the verb) to talk about how to do something, but the "to" is missing here.
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Add "to" to make this a to-infinitive.

instance_text.source: She's gorgeous. If she would only take off her glasses maybe other people will notice it too. '
instance_text.corrected: She's gorgeous. If she would only take off her glasses maybe other people would notice it too. '

feedback.feedback_explanation: If you start a hypothetical conditional with "if... would only," the result should have "would."
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Change "will" to "would" here to fix this conditional.

instance_text.source: In contrast, his wife respected and loved his mother and never complain to her husband about these bad situations.
instance_text.corrected: In contrast, his wife respected and loved his mother and never complained to her husband about these bad situations.

feedback.feedback_explanation: It seems like this happened in the past, but you are using the present tense.
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Try changing "complain" to the past tense.

instance_text.source: First of all, finishing high school is a passege of life that indicates the beginning of a new chapter for students.
instance_text.corrected: First of all, finishing high school is a rite of passage that indicates the beginning of a new chapter for students.

feedback.feedback_explanation: It seems that you are thinking of the phrase "rite of passage," which would fit well here.
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Change "passege of life" to "rite of passage."

instance_text.source: Then the friends could not fail to pay attention to the Alison's words.
instance_text.corrected: Then the friends could not fail to pay attention to [NONE] Alison's words.

feedback.feedback_explanation: Articles like "the" can not be combined with possessives like "Alison's."

instance_text.source: The reason is, three days ago, he had been working when a girl at his work asked him whether he had a girlfriend and he said 'I had one, come on, you know my ex - girlfriend', then she just walked away without tell anything.
instance_text.corrected: The reason is, three days ago, he had been working when a girl at his work asked him whether he had a girlfriend and he said 'I had one, come on, you know my ex - girlfriend', then she just walked away without saying anything.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Say" may be better than "tell" here. "Tell" is used to say something specific to someone. "Say" is more general.

instance_text.source: I like trying dishes from all over the world and I am keen on cooking and experimenting [NONE] new exotic cuisines.
instance_text.corrected: I like trying dishes from all over the world and I am keen on cooking and experimenting with new exotic cuisines.

feedback.feedback_explanation: When the verb "experiment" is used with a direct object like "new exotic cuisines," the preposition "with" must be used as a connector.

instance_text.source: Not to mention the social bonding ability of it, while game tension between the opposing teams is somewhat inevitable, the irreverent, human, no - strings - attached nature of streetball events always compensate [NONE] its negative aspects which, upon closer inspection, appear to be shared between every single sports event.
instance_text.corrected: Not to mention the social bonding ability of it, while game tension between the opposing teams is somewhat inevitable, the irreverent, human, no - strings - attached nature of streetball events always compensate for its negative aspects which, upon closer inspection, appear to be shared between every single sports event.

feedback.feedback_explanation: When used in this way, "compensate" needs a preposition, "for," to connect to its object.

instance_text.source: Everyone is terrified and find out that a demon is attached to the doll.
instance_text.corrected: Everyone is terrified and finds out that a demon is attached to the doll.

feedback.feedback_explanation: The subject "everyone" is singular, so the sentence needs a third-person singular verb.
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Change "find" to the third-person singular form.

instance_text.source: Being raised in an environment where personal autonomy is the core, children with disabilities were growing [NONE] very independent and strong, despite all the challenges they could face along the way.
instance_text.corrected: Being raised in an environment where personal autonomy is the core, children with disabilities were growing up very independent and strong, despite all the challenges they could face along the way.

feedback.feedback_explanation: Perhaps you are thinking of the phrasal verb "grow up."

instance_text.source: I was so angry, because I was finishing the puzzles and five pieces were missing. So I began to search the whole house for the five pieces but didn't find them.
instance_text.corrected: I was so angry, because I was finishing the puzzle and five pieces were missing. So I began to search the whole house for the five pieces but didn't find them.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Puzzles" is plural here, but it seems like you are talking about only one.

instance_text.source: To solve this problem, the city should set up more space and facilities for skateboarding, and separate the different space for walking and skateboarding.
instance_text.corrected: To solve this problem, the city should set up more space and facilities for skateboarding, and separate the different spaces for walking and skateboarding.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Space" should be plural here, not singular. Sometimes, "space" is an uncountable noun, but in this sentence, there is more than one distinct area, which can be counted.

instance_text.source: One day in the morning, Paxton waited for Long and the writer, but he heard that someone was calling him. Suddenly, he goes to the beach and is killed by the shadow.
instance_text.corrected: One day in the morning, Paxton was waiting for Long and the writer, but he heard that someone was calling him. Suddenly, he goes to the beach and is killed by the shadow.

feedback.feedback_explanation: Use the past continuous (is/was plus the -ing form of the verb) for something that was currently happening at a past time you are talking about.

instance_text.source: The second problem is about that some apparatus are not working well because the school didn't maintenance a since long time ago.
instance_text.corrected: The second problem is about that some apparatus are not working well because the school hasn't done maintenance a since long time ago.

feedback.feedback_explanation: Use the present perfect (has/hasn't + past participle) for a situation that started in the past and continues now.

instance_text.source: Everyone's nervous except for Jerome Tanny, last year's champion, famous for his threatening pre - start grin, that we all call [NONE] 'Shark's Smile'.
instance_text.corrected: Everyone's nervous except for Jerome Tanny, last year's champion, famous for his threatening pre - start grin, that we all call the 'Shark's Smile'.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Shark's Smile" is missing the article "the." "The" is common when using the nickname or title for a specific, special thing.

instance_text.source: Only possible in segmental pronunciation, the occasional missed a few notes, such as -d, I did not noticed this because when I deliberately stressed -d, I found the tone and mood more likely to become very weird. This is the biggest problem I've encountered in pronunciation teaching.
instance_text.corrected: Only possible in segmental pronunciation, the occasional missed a few notes, such as -d, I did not notice this because when I deliberately stressed -d, I found the tone and mood more likely to become very weird. This is the biggest problem I've encountered in pronunciation teaching.

feedback.feedback_explanation: When using a verb in the past with "did not," the verb itself should be in the base form.

instance_text.source: Now, to answer your question, I have many favourite places near my town because I live in a lovely little town, but there is one place that is special for me: 'A Fervenza do Pedregal'. '
instance_text.corrected: Now, to answer your question, I have many favourite places near my town because I live in a lovely little town, but there is one place that is special to me: 'A Fervenza do Pedregal'. '

feedback.feedback_explanation: The pattern "special... to (person)" is used to show which person feels that something is special.
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Change "for" to "to" to fix this phrase.

instance_text.source: But, the fact that it is short distance doesn't mean it will be easy or something like that.
instance_text.corrected: But, the fact that it is short distance doesn't mean it will be easy or anything like that.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Something" is used for positive contexts. "Anything" is better for negative contexts like this.

instance_text.source: Our flat and houses make the other animals lose their homes, and it leads to environmental deterioration.
instance_text.corrected: Our flats and houses make the other animals lose their homes, and it leads to environmental deterioration.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Flat" is singular here, but you seem to be talking about more than one.

instance_text.source: That being said, I still feel the reasons I have presented are strong ones, such as architecture and computer system.
instance_text.corrected: That being said, I still feel the reasons I have presented are strong ones, such as architecture and computer systems.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Computer system" is singular, but you seem to be referring to many, or all of them in general.

instance_text.source: This is the result that something new has occurred and they want to collect information.
instance_text.corrected: This is because something new has occurred and they want to collect information.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "This is the result that" is not a natural phrase to explain why something from a previous sentence happened.
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Consider an alternate phrasing such as "this is because..."

instance_text.source: To begin with is design, we have to considerate background colour, artwork, and security issues, and then we are supposed to prepare metal plates, using skilled machinists.
instance_text.corrected: To begin with is design, we have to consider background colour, artwork, and security issues, and then we are supposed to prepare metal plates, using skilled machinists.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Considerate" is an adjective, but it is being used as a verb here.

instance_text.source: My favourite restaurant is situated in Modugno.
instance_text.corrected: My favourite restaurant is [NONE] in Modugno.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Is situated in" may sound a little stiff and formal.
feedback.feedback_suggestion: Consider a more common way to say this, such as "is in."

instance_text.source: These were my first feeling when I made the mistake.
instance_text.corrected: These were my first feelings when I made the mistake.

feedback.feedback_explanation: "Feeling" is singular here, but in this context, there would be many. A plural is more appropriate.

instance_text.source: We took all we needed and started the searching for Niall... We went to all the caves in Los Angeles, but we couldn't find them.
instance_text.corrected: We took all we needed and started the search for Niall... We went to all the caves in Los Angeles, but we couldn't find them.

feedback.feedback_explanation: It is not necessary to change the verb "search" to "searching" here. There is a noun, "search," that can be used for this process.

instance_text.source: Right after getting off the plane, she traveled to his dorm to meet him with a view to satisfying her long waiting for him.
instance_text.corrected: Right after getting off the plane, she traveled to his dorm to meet him with a view to satisfying her long wait for him.

feedback.feedback_explanation: It is not necessary to change the verb "wait" to "waiting" here. There is a noun, "wait," that can be used for this process.
